TITLE I--BAYLEE'S LAW

SEC. 101. SHORT TITLE.

This title may be cited as ``Baylee's Law''.

SEC. 102. SAFETY AND SECURITY OF CHILDREN IN CHILDCARE FACILITIES.

The Public Buildings Act of 1959 is amended by adding a section on the safety and security of children in childcare facilities. Before enrolling a child in a childcare facility in a public building under the Administrator's control, parents must receive written notification identifying current tenants and the building's security level. Additionally, parents must be informed of any new Federal tenants scheduled to occupy the building. The Administrator must notify parents of children in childcare facilities in public buildings of any serious threats to safety or security. A comprehensive report on childcare facilities must be submitted to Congress within a year of this section's enactment. The Administrator must assess safety and security levels of childcare facilities in public buildings and provide recommendations for enhancement. This includes examining windows and interior furnishings for protective measures against natural disasters or terrorist attacks. The Administrator must assess safety and security levels of childcare facilities in public buildings, including examining windows and interior furnishings for protective measures against natural disasters or terrorist attacks, such as the deadly effect of flying glass. TITLE II--FEDERAL PROTECTIVE SERVICE REFORM

SEC. 201. SHORT TITLE. This title may be cited as the ``Federal Protective Service Reform Act of 2000''.

SEC. 202. DESIGNATION OF POLICE OFFICERS. Amends the Act of June 1, 1948 to designate "special policemen" as "police officers" and update terminology.

SEC. 203. POWERS. The Act of June 1, 1948 is amended to grant additional powers to police officers, including the authority to carry firearms, petition for arrest warrants, execute warrants, and make warrantless arrests if a crime is witnessed or probable cause exists. The Act of June 1, 1948 amended to grant police officers additional powers, including carrying firearms, executing warrants, and making arrests with probable cause. The Commissioner of the Federal Protective Service must issue regulations for these powers to take effect, and the Administrator can make agreements with State and local governments for authority outside federal property. The Act of June 1, 1948 amended to grant police officers additional powers, including carrying firearms, executing warrants, and making arrests with probable cause. The Commissioner of the Federal Protective Service must issue regulations for these powers to take effect, and the Administrator can make agreements with State and local governments for authority outside federal property, allowing officers to exercise powers in adjacent areas. SEC. 204. PENALTIES.

Amends the Act of June 1, 1948 to impose fines or imprisonment for violating regulations under section 2.

SEC. 205. SPECIAL AGENTS.

Amends the Act of June 1, 1948 to replace "nonuniformed special policemen" with "special agents" and grants special agents authority outside Federal property. SEC. 206. ESTABLISHMENT OF FEDERAL PROTECTIVE SERVICE. Amends the Act of June 1, 1948 to establish the Federal Protective Service. The Federal Protective Service is established as a separate operating service of the General Services Administration. It will be headed by a Commissioner with at least 5 years of law enforcement experience, who will report directly to the Administrator. The Commissioner's duties include assisting the Administrator and serving as the law enforcement officer and security official of the United States. The Federal Protective Service, under the General Services Administration, is responsible for protecting Federal officers and employees in US-owned buildings. They provide assistance to other law enforcement agencies and coordinate activities with the Public Buildings Service Commissioner. This does not affect the duties of the Secret Service. Regional Directors and Assistant Directors are appointed as well. The Commissioner of the Federal Protective Service may appoint regional directors and assistant commissioners with specific law enforcement experience requirements. Additionally, the pay level for the Commissioner is specified in title 5 of the United States Code. SEC. 207 of the Act of June 1, 1948 is amended to include a survey by the Director of the Office of Personnel Management on pay and benefits of Federal police forces to address disparities. A report with findings and recommendations is to be submitted to Congress within 12 months. SEC. 208 addresses the number of police officers in the same Act. SEC. 8 states that there must be at least 730 full-time equivalent police officers in the Federal Protective Service after a 1-year period. This number cannot be reduced unless authorized by law. SEC. 209 outlines employment standards and training for security personnel contracted for buildings owned or occupied by the United States. SEC. 210 authorizes appropriations for these purposes. Authorization of appropriations is granted from the Federal Buildings Fund to carry out the Act.
